awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Admixture mapping of a hybrid zone to test Tinbergen's emancipation hypothesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how genes cause the behavioral traits of different species to be different is a major goal of evolutionary biology.  This project seeks to test the emancipation hypothesis proposed by Tinbergen 60 years ago to understand how a novel behavior arises by using a hybrid zone between two species of hummingbirds. The novel behavior is a courtship display that is performed by one species, Allen's Hummingbird, and not the other, Rufous Hummingbird. In this stereotyped display, called the 'pendulum display', the male flies back and forth over a female while producing distinctive sounds with his wings. The investigators will record displays from 400 birds from within a hybrid zone between these two species, and then search for genes associated with individual components of the behavior, by sequencing the genomes of these 400 birds. Understanding how one behavior splits into two will reveal a fundamental mechanism of how behavior evolves.  Additionally, this grant will train of students of diverse backgrounds, and enable outreach to the California School for the Deaf, Riverside by funding purchase of an 'acoustic camera', allowing deaf children to learn more about sound through this newly invented way of visualizing it. 

As the genetic underpinnings of how one behavior splits into two 'paramorphs', alternate forms of a previously unitary character, have not been demonstrated for any behavior, the analyses presented here aim to do so for the first time. This 3-year study has three objectives: (1) Hybrid zone mapping and cline analysis: phenotype, genotype, and selection (2): Sequence analysis of complex display behavior, and (3): Admixture mapping of behavior and morphology. Together these objectives will provide information about selection on the display traits of interest, and test the paramorph hypothesis directly, using phenotypic and genotypic data respectively. Current data indicate no fixed genetic differences between the species within coding regions of the genome, hinting that the paramorphic behavior could be driven by differences in gene regulation between the two species, rather than as the result of a paralogous gene.  Just as the modern view of morphological diversity was transformed by the study of its genetic basis, a direct assessment of the genes underlying a behavior that varies across a hybrid zone will allow one of the first tests of how a complex motor pattern has evolved. This project will build infrastructure through addition of sound, video, and specimens to the Macaulay Library at Cornell University, San Diego Natural History Museum and the SDSU Museum of Biodiversity.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This project investigates a fundamental area of biology: how is biodiversity generated? In other words, how do new species form? This process is called speciation, and in birds, it often involves courtship displays. We focused on two closely related species of hummingbirds, the Allen's Hummingbird and the Rufous Hummingbird. Each species produces unique courtship sounds with their tails and also have unique courtship behaviors. The courtship behaviors are often given in specific sequences and involve flight patterns like dives and pendulum-like back and forth dips. We studied the genetics, physical appearance, and behaviors of these two species in several different populations. We found a hybrid zone where these two species interbreed that spans the coast of southern Oregon and extends inland along the Klamath River in northern California. We recorded and described courtship displays and sounds both inside and outside the hybrid zone and also developed a novel method for quantifying behavioral sequences. We found species-specific courtship displays that were performed outside the hybrid zone. Surprisingly, hybrid zone birds sometimes produce behaviors in a sequential order not found in either parental species. We also sequenced genomes of these birds. We found specific genetic regions that seem to correspond to specific behavioral characters; therefore, we may have uncovered the genetic underpinnings of behaviors important in speciation of these birds. We also performed genetic analyses that help us understand the population history of these birds across the geographic region they occupy. These analyses help us determine how the hybrid zone formed and regions where the species has been expanding. Our studies also showed the importance of thorough geographic sampling when assessing demographic history in the presence of gene flow. 

Broader Impacts:

This project contributed to the STEM workforce by training students in bioinformatics, genomics, museum science, and modern behavioral methods. Two graduate students were trained as part of this project; both are members of underrepresented groups in STEM fields. One earned PhD and was the first in his family to attend college. He has subsequently been hired as a tenure-track professor. A second student is finishing her MS degree. This project also supported four undergraduate students. One of these students subsequently earned a MS degree at another institution. This research was disseminated to the public through five journal articles, two graduate theses, and nine presentations to scientific societies and conservation organizations. Specimens and genetic samples from this project were deposited in two different museums. Thus, these specimens and samples contribute to overall biological infrastructure and can be used by researchers in the future. Lastly, some of the results produced from this project have implications on conservation and wildlife management. For example, we were able to verify the species status of the two hummingbirds involved. In addition, we characterized the genetic divergence of subspecies within one of the species. Furthermore, this study investigates characteristics that underly speciation. This information helps us understand how biodiversity is generated, knowledge that is fundamental to preserving biodiversity in our changing world.
